task_description: Predicting which text is more persuasive between pairs of arguments. The task explores linguistic features that contribute to effective persuasion in written communication

argument_1.description: First argument of the paired arguments

argument_2.description: Second argument of the paired arguments

label.description: Which argument is more persuasive, i.e., which argument is more likely to convince the reader.

known_hypotheses: **Two-sided arguments** tend to be more persuasive for highly educated people as proponents put forward their own points and then also describe some of their opponents' points.
Arguments that appear at the **beginning of a message (primacy effect) or at the end of a message (recency effect)** can be more persuasive.
In certain circumstances, **several component arguments** are better than a single argument, and **repetition of similar arguments** may also be more persuasive than a single presentation.
The use of **explicit organizational markers** can improve the writing quality and persuasiveness of essays.
**Arguments using statistics and examples** are positively correlated with persuasiveness.
